#T_SP=webanno.custom.Groundobject|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Target|
#Text=The Moor of Rannoch THE FAMOUS HEAT-WAVE of June 1949 persisted into July .
#Text=The drought afflicting the whole country became chronic .
#Text=West highland villages had to get water brought in by carrier , and that was something I had not heard of before .
#Text=Conditions for rock-climbing had never been better : I could think of some new routes that I wanted to try .
#Text=And yet-I thought also of the Moor of Rannoch .
#Text=It is the greatest moor in Scotland , one of the most accessible too , yet curiously enough the least explored .
#Text=It is vast and trackless .
#Text=Perhaps that intimidates walkers ?
#Text=While mountaineers , who like deserts if they like anything , notoriously prefer their deserts vertical .
#Text=Too long had I been counted among the latter .
#Text=At first , while my ignorance was darkest and heaviest , Rannoch Moor was damned just because it was flat-that was enough !

#Text=Later , when cold reason was admitted to my counsels , it was damned because it was bleak , bare , featureless , and quite excessively extensive , therefore no fit place for a hill-lover , to whom a peak is paradise ; and no whit short of hell in foul weather , when damp mists sink on to it , prospectless , and the bogs are full , or when snow-winds scourge it .
#Text=So that in the end Rannoch Moor had to conquer me through my heart , and reason had to follow perception , not lead .
#Text=Which is just .

#Text=It was that eastern view from the Glencoe summits that won me-the sparkle of the numberless tarns at noon-the phosphorescent gleam of their night-eyes-the spike of Schichallion pushing up beyond blue haze at the farther rim , thirty miles away .

#Text=I had been fascinated , too , by the distant sight of wild swans and great flights of smaller birds coming on to Loch Ba and Loch Laidon , which stretch in a linked waterway ten miles across the moor .

#Text=The scene from my watch-tower on the Buachaille showed me that the most interesting way of crossing the moor would be to keep close to the main chain of waterways , which rise in the Blackmount at Coire Ba of Stab Ghabhar , and run east through Lochan na Stainge , Loch Ba , and the five miles of Loch Laidon to Loch Rannoch-a distance of fifteen miles .
#Text=Loch Rannoch continues beyond the moor fifteen miles to Schichallion , thence by the Tummel and Tay to the North Sea .
#Text=The moor 's northern boundary is the group of low hills called the Black Carries , the south boundary the high group of Achallader .
#Text=Its entire area is said to be fifty-six square miles .

#Text=My reason , now stripped of its old prejudice , informed me that from the centre of this unvisited moorland all the mountains circling round its rims would be seen anew , and charms not as yet known to me revealed .
#Text=And of the moor 's own secrets what did I really know ?
#Text=Not a thing .
#Text=On an evening of mid-July I arrived by road at the south-west side of the moor and camped between Lochan na Stainge and Loch Ba .
#Text=I came alone .
#Text=Let me confess at once that I prefer being alone among hills , provided that I am not climbing in the technical sense ; prefer it also on moors , unless in dirty weather .
#Text=But on this occasion I was not quite alone .
#Text=I had as company a Golden Labrador bitch called Heather .

#Text=She is a fine mountaineer with sufficient tops to her credit and ability enough on rock and snow to satisfy the Scrutinising Committee of the Scottish Mountaineering Club , from membership of which club she is disqualified only by sex .
#Text=Her big black pads give her a grip on slabs and a quick , confident technique superior to that of her envious owner .
#Text=Like me she is twice as much alive among hills as at sea level .
#Text=And she does n't talk .
#Text=She just looks ; which is quite enough .
#Text=We pitched the tent well to the east of Loch Ba because damp grey mist was rising off all the lochans .
#Text=The day had been very hot .
#Text=The fog , however , in appearance if not in temperature , was much like a mid-winter 's ground mist .
#Text=It cohered in banks , gently rolling sometimes this way and sometimes that , for no apparent reason-the night being windless .
#Text=The sinuous sway of its forms would have been a perfect medium for the weird display of light had only the moon been full .
#Text=But the stars were strong in a black sky and the mists greyly chill .
#Text=I had deliberately pitched the tent on top of thick heather and thus had a springy couch under me for my night 's sleep .
#Text=The other Heather curled up at my feet .
#Text=After the experimental nibbles at my toes were over she made an excellent hot-water bottle .
#Text=We rose at sunrise .
#Text=Not a trace of mist remained ; nor was there any cloud in the sky .

#Text=So striking was the latter fact that I realized how often in the past I must have talked about cloudless skies without ever having spoken strict truth , save in reference to a narrow view from close country .

#Text=In the wider mountain skyscape , always , in some quarter of that mountain sky there has been cloud , perhaps a long bar of cumulus low down at the horizon , or a few puffs glimpsed through a pass .
#Text=But to-day east , north , west , and south-clear sky , peculiarly and luminously empty like a heavenly vacuum .
#Text=From behind the blue a colourless radiance shone , more than usually suggestive of infinite space and of the reality of that infinity .
#Text=Provided that this were seen at all there could be engendered only one attitude of mind , that of a reverential awe .
#Text=After sharing the dog 's breakfast I struck camp and left the tent at the roadside to be collected later by passing friends .
#Text=By six we were away .

#Text=The early start was necessary because I intended to make a double traverse-ten miles north-east to Rannoch station , then thirteen miles west back to Kingshouse , Glencoe-and because I had a strong suspicion that distances on Rannoch Moor were to be measured in time , not miles .
#Text=The first passage along the east side of Loch Ba gave us the heaviest going of the day ; the heather was longer there and the ground broken by hummocky ridges and old water-courses .
#Text=A short and twisting river linked Loch Ba to Loch Laidon .
#Text=It was at these two ends of the two lochs that I had seen wild swans fly in and duck come down among the heather .

#Text=In the breeding season black- and red-throated divers visit the lochs and behave like submarines when alarmed , slowly submerging until only the head and neck remain above water , like a periscope .
#Text=The wide mosses farther away from the lochs harbour greenshanks .
#Text=And that is the limit of my knowledge about Rannoch bird life , which is certain to be very much more extensive than I ever dream .
#Text=These lochs would repay the bird-watcher .
#Text=I should be most interested to know , for example , what birds find food or shelter on the wooded islands .
#Text=They are small islands , well wooded with birch , yew , and pine-indicating that Rannoch Moor might yet revert to its Old Wood of Caledon days were it not for the hungry deer .
#Text=I should like to be spared the wolves , the brown bear , the boar , and the outlawed brigands , but the natural forest that sheltered them I would have back if I could .

#Text=New growth seems to flourish on the water-protected isles , which are inaccessible except to a man prepared to swim a hundred yards-and , if he wants to botanize or bird-watch , to push a raft with his clothing in front of him .
#Text=On reaching Loch Laidon I thought that the ground improved , although a certain amount of leaping from tuft to tuft was still part of the day 's work .
#Text=On the other hand there were surprisingly few peat-hags .
#Text=I remember no more than one or two , still exposing the bare bones of the Old Wood , but I imagine that in other parts of the moor they must be abundant .
#Text=On the line I chose , always close to the loch , the moor was well drained , and over its whole area I judge it to be equally well drained by the countless tarns .
#Text=I met no bogs .
#Text=One gets across in dry weather with dry feet .
#Text=Admittedly we had the moor in perfect condition .
#Text=A west wind was blowing , of the kind we may truly call a zephyr , but the heat was semi-tropical , and away from the waterways must have been as consumingly fierce as the south Syrian desert .
#Text=Unlike Loch Ba , Loch Laidon had a fairly straight margin : we could travel close to the shore , which we found indented by innumerable tiny bays .
#Text=These were filled with a clean and gravelly sand , most tempting on a hot day .
#Text=We had one bathe near the start , and ten minutes later , feeling as hot as ever , we had another .
#Text=There were going to be more .
#Text=Faced with the personal example of Heather 's ever-readiness , I began to see my own repeated dressing and undressing as a pointless waste of time .
#Text=There was little or no chance of meeting any one during the day .
#Text=So I stripped once and for all and stuffed my clothes into my rucksack .
#Text=The zephyr could now get at my skin , and the need for frequent dips became less urgent .
#Text=But for the bays our day would fast have become a sheer trial of endurance-worse by far for Heather than for me , her great handicap being fur and a lack of sweat-glands .
#Text=During the first few hours'enthusiasm she covered three times as much ground as I , ranging out eastwards in wide circles .
#Text=I let her do this to see what game she might start up .
#Text=It astonished me that she drew a blank .
#Text=Not one hare , not a rabbit or grouse , did she raise-absolutely nothing .
#Text=The moor at this time of day seems to be bare of all animal life .
#Text=Throughout our traverse I never once set eyes on a deer , although every winter great herds congregate by the roadside .
#Text=I assumed that they would all be up in the corries of the Blackmount .
#Text=The lack of other life is stranger .
#Text=We came to the north-east end of Loch Laidon where the River Gaur flowed out sharply right towards Loch Rannoch .
#Text=The river must have been fifty yards wide .
#Text=I hoped that it might be all the shallower on that account , and tried to get across by wading , my rucksack balanced on my head .
#Text=Before I was a third of the way over the water had crept up to my chin , and by natural buoyancy my body was tending to float and capsize .
#Text=Since the water looked much deeper and swifter in front , I came back and moved on a few hundred yards , then tried again with no more success .
#Text=In the end we had to make a half-mile detour downstream to a ford , where a line of great boulders offered a dry route .
#Text=After all my vain efforts to wade I was determined to wade at the last , and did so through chest-deep water .

#Text=On the other hand Heather , who had already swum the river twice , and been forced each time to return in high dudgeon because I had failed to follow , was determined that since the ford was now found she would use it .
#Text=She bounded clumsily on the polished boulders , not being able to get a good purchase on them with her wet paws , and landing each time in a splashing sprawl .
#Text=But she was over long before I was .
#Text=We had now been going four hours .
#Text=Cutting out the last few hundred yards to Rannoch station we rounded the head of Loch Laidon .
#Text=There we struck an excellent track going half a mile back along the farther shore , en route to Kingshouse , then suddenly degenerating into a mere sheep-track .
#Text=This northern shore was decidedly pleasanter than the southern shore .
#Text=The sun was shining in front instead of behind , and there were wild flowers by the path .
#Text=One little bay was full of water-lilies , and another , about a mile down the loch , had the best of all the sandy beaches .
#Text=We turned aside on to the latter .
#Text=It was backed by short granite crags , and covered deeply in coarse clean sand , on to which the sun had been beating several hours daily for a month .
#Text=It was hot to lie on .
#Text=There I lay , my back upon the warm granite , and lunched with Heather .
#Text=On this side of the loch the shore shelved more steeply ; one could dive in after a knee-deep wade .
#Text=From time to time one or the other of us would rise and go down to the water for a plunge , then come back and sprawl .
#Text=An hour passed away .
#Text=We just luxuriated .

#Text=Sometimes I would wonder whether to have one more swim in those blue waters or to go on towards the wide , sunlit corries of the Blachnount , or to the glens of Glencoe where the peaks were darkening against the sun .
#Text=The walk to Kingshouse would certainly be the shorter , and even so was consuming time in a way that I had not believed possible .
#Text=Twelve more miles , said the map ?
#Text=I had better allow six hours for it .
#Text=In due course we continued three miles up the loch-side , until at the ruined cottage called Tigh na Cruaiche the track swung away to the west , aiming straight for Glencoe .
#Text=The so-called ' track'had long since become a purely imaginary line on the map , having no basis in a present reality .
#Text=At the south wall of the ruin a barn still provides roof and shelter in foul weather .

#Text=I could think of no better headquarters for a natural historian bent on adventure , or for bird-watchers or fishermen for only a hundred feet ; for only a hundred feet below , a great bay of the loch contains seven islands , two of which are well wooded .
#Text=No one will find comfort at Tigh na Cruaiche ; only bare shelter and perfect solitude .
#Text=We had still to cover four and a half miles to reach the Black Corries Lodge .
#Text=This part of the day we both found most exhausting .
#Text=Heather was now following close to heel of her own free will .
#Text=For my part I found the ground badly folded and the heather too thick .
#Text=Only now was the day-long breeze strengthening and beginning to feel rather too cool on my unprotected skin , so that when the lodge came into sight I was glad enough to put on clothing .
#Text=The average height of the moor is a thousand feet ; the lodge around twelve hundred : it thus commands a wondrously wide prospect across Loch Ba to the Blackmount .
#Text=Had the tarns all been tiny the moor might have resembled a cratered battlefield ; but the waters were broad and long enough to add beauty to desolation , both of their kind matchless .

#Text=The circling hills of the east and west Blackmount , and the deep ranks of Glencoe , were in proper perspective , full in stature , clean-carved by corrie and glen , a deep and dusky blue in the hollows .
#Text=I realized that not until this day had I ever seen the Glencoe hills as they really are .
#Text=From the glen itself the mountains are sadly foreshortened , but this fact is never guessed , never realized , until one goes miles out on to Rannoch Moor .
#Text=I have no especial love for road-walking-a road is a tyrant , directing a man in ways planned for him , and most wearing on climbing-nails , which are costly .
#Text=But I have a good word to say for the road from Black Corries Lodge to Kingshouse : it is only four miles and downhill all the way .
#Text=I could appreciate that , in the circumstances .
#Text=I was very tired .
#Text=And a good dinner being only one hour away , I found myself still full of enthusiasm for the moor of Rannoch ; for its own sake as well as for its new revelation of old hills .
#Text=At last I knew it-and at that checked myself .
#Text=Moors , like mountains , are not known so easily as first visits tempt one to think .
#Text=However , I had seen something of it in summer .
#Text=What of winter ?
#Text=In winter I knew only the moor 's western fringes .

#Text=I had watched the sun shine low over wind-rippled snow-fields , and glance across frozen lochs , make of an ice-bound tree a flashing chandelier and strike fire from the frozen tower of Buachaille .

#Text=A winter traverse of the whole moor would give a man these and other things , and an adventure into the bargain for which he would have to be as fit and as well clothed as for a mountain expedition .
#Text=I had had enough experience of Rannoch blizzards to know that they rival Cairngorm blizzards in everything save wind velocity .
#Text=In new , deep snow a crossing in one day would hardly be possible , but on old snow , in hard frost and fine weather , all should be more than well .
#Text=It may be that I exaggerate the worth of the day ?
#Text=It does seem to ask strenuous work and a sacrifice of either comfort or convenience .
#Text=However , greater worth has always in my own experience asked greater effort , and the reward has borne proportion to effort , on one plane or another .
#Text=Summer and winter there is a day for Rannoch .
#Text=
